fields.body:
Welcome to my new blogging site (though it’s out of my vanity to say “new” here because I never had one before, but who says “new” can only denote recreation but not mere creation, if this is the case, how the hell life will be for engineers slash CS 107 students who work on pointers). Yeah, right, I know you’re now imaging (or, with a tremendously higher probability, you’re cursing about my ridiculous logic, emancipated imagination, chaotic writing style, and wondering what the heck the p-word is (I mean, for sure, innocently, “pointer”)) the line of code “Blog *my_blog = new Blog()”, which seems ridiculous at the first sight; but, I bet you will accept its legitimacy if you’ve ever been familiar with its ultimate fantasy-form “Girl *girl_friend = new Girl(/*parameter omitted*/). Anyway, this preamble is way too long-winded, but this is undeniably my style. Whether you like this or not, I don’t care. (NG, I do care.) I just wanted to create a suspense here but it seems like English (or Chinese) does not support this function. This is the reason why I learned Japanese, because then you can append the verb and its negation-conjugation at the end of the sentence and say, with the mysterious tone Kojima Haruna used for her speech at this year’s General Election, “I :: Whether you like my blog or not :: Car~~e”. (みんなこのブログに気に入るかどうか、僕は気にしていまー(pause for 5 seconds)ーす).

So, back to the introduction of my blog. I dubbed it “MICHAELISM” because I have to give it a name (slapped >), because, I was inundated by “-ism” words throughout this quarter in my philosophy class and this is the time when Newton’s law of inertia applies to something other than physics. I do think my flow of thoughts and the essences slash garbages contained (yeah, I admitted there are garbages. If the DNA of human beings can contain 99% garbage then at least I’m sure the garbage rate of my blog will be at least higher than that) are representative of my life philosophy, and I do hope to share these with everyone given that you are willing to give your precious s*** to me (Jk). Now, when I type Michaelism, there still comes the annoying red wavy underline, so one of my life ambitions is just, simply, get rid of this line for all the computers with their pre-installed operating systems in the world (oops, what about the International Space Station, let’s say, entire universe, counting the spacecraft Matthew McConaughey is piloting).

The last thing, my blog is going to be multi-lingual, so please refrain from bombarding me if you could not understand anything for some of my blogs. The working languages will be English, Chinese and Japanese, and I guess these are enough because they already covered the top three countries on the GDP chart (though this is not an accurate prediction that the fourth language that I will learn is German). I’m trying to digress from monochromic and bland academic writing in my blog and give my English a chance to be naughty, willful and unbounded (just like the way I talk, unscrupulously and sometimes stupidly, if you happen to be my friend on campus). Also, I would like to sustain my ability to write Chinese essays (ok, more precisely, “type”) and practice my Japanese writing skills. I just found that I really like languages (expressing, bull***ing, witticism, humor, comedy..). In particular, I just love talking and writing and accordingly I told my friends that these two skills are in my bucket list for my life with the highest priority. So here I come, as a qualified student, but totally unqualified writer, unqualified comedian, unqualified polyglot (I HATE THIS WORD because I said I would like to be a “polygamist” at frat rush). But this is better than making no noise at all and just letting everything rotten inside my mind, isn’t it.

Yeah, welcome to “MICHAELISM”, welcome!.
fields.title: Hello World to My New Blog
fields.preface: I started my WordPress blog on December, 2014 and this blog post was its intro and my first attempt on gibberish style. I pretty much abandoned the WordPress blog because one, the management panel is just too inflexible for my whimsical needs, two, WordPress is blocked in China.

fields.body:
前段时间有一个朋友发来短信说，我的人人、微信朋友圈和Facebook都停更了，一定是过于现充无暇顾及这些社交网站。这是有些夸赞的成分了，实际上我只是不知道更新什么，也没有时间好好去思考怎么把故事讲好，所以就自然而然地懈怠了。秋季学期刚刚结束，正好闲了下来，新开了这个博客，也想把自己这个大半年经历的、感受的慢慢从肚子中搜刮出来，组织起来，分享给大家。所以作为我的博客的第一篇日志，也算是对三个月来我在社交网络上的空缺做一个补偿，让我来细细说说这个学期究竟在我的生活中发生了什么。中文好久不用了已略有生锈，遣词造句什么的难免有所退化，所以还请各位多多包涵。

今年暑假我在日本东京呆了三个月，从六月下旬到九月中旬，先在日语学校学习了两个月，然后先后参加了慶應義塾大学和哈佛大学以及我校合办的两个交流项目HPAIR和SKIP。走遍了东京的各种大街小巷，参加了学校的日语演讲比赛，尝试了去结交来自各个国家的狐朋狗友，总而言之，是一段很长但是在回忆中很支离破碎的一段经历。

三个月后我很难再用一个词去概括这个国家，或者用哪个代表性的元素去描述这个国家。当有朋友问起我，日本是一个怎么样的国家，我不知道怎么回答，直到有一天我觉得我找到了一个还算过得去的答案：日本是一个极其矛盾的国家。自相矛盾是我在日本感触最深的一点。举例而言，日本社会是一个高度统一的社会，在电车上你能看到所有的男性上班族（サラリーマン）穿着看上去毫无差别的白色衬衣和黑色西裤，所有人的谈吐举止都高度符合社会“契约”，以至于每次早高峰我坐电车上学的时候一直感到很格格不入。我会刻意不去穿鲜艳颜色的上衣，这样在人群中也不至于太突兀，直到后来参加HPAIR的时候需要着正装出席，我才觉得坐电车能松一口气。但是与此相对的，这个社会却允许并且能与很多奇特的亚文化相共存，比如穿女子高生制服装的老爷爷，夸张萝莉塔风的女孩，打鼻钉唇钉厚底鞋厚度超过十厘米的原宿朋克风，秋叶原宅文化等等。这些人可以堂而皇之地走在马路上（诚然，这是他们的权利），而且过路的人大都可以对他们视而不见，罕有怒目相视的情况。或许是大家已经见多了这样的异文化，见怪不怪，或许他们只是在心里默默地数落而不会将这些事情坦白地说出来抨击。但是说实在的，在日本呆的时间长了每个人自身都会产生强烈的“求同”之心，它会慢慢内化，最终就算不在乎外界的目光或者言语，自己内心也会有一种强烈的排斥力（或者说自尊）来约束自身的社会行为。而愿意大张旗鼓地发扬异文化的人，说不定也有这样一段求同的历史，也许是因为得不到外界认同或者心生对单一化社会的厌倦，破罐子破摔，不再受制于社会束缚才将自己的个性发扬光大。除此之外，我印象深刻的矛盾还有：日本人有比中国人更加严重的崇洋媚外的心理，所谓的“憧れ”，但是日本社会却是极度封闭绝对不接纳外国人，甚至是混血但是在日本长大的“日本（国籍）人”（ハーフ）。日本是一个收敛、内向的民族，说话礼貌婉转，待人接物极其注重礼仪，但也是一个校园欺凌最严重最普遍，在二战期间做出过残忍而非人道的作为的国家。如此种种，不一而足。

不过写到这里，我又开始些动摇了，因为与其说这个国家是一个矛盾体，不如说我们不应该将一个民族千千万万的人笼统地概括在一起，用一个标准去评价。但是仔细想来，很多时候这些矛盾所针对的不是一个民族，而单单就是一个个人而已。一个人可以求同存异，可以迷恋外国而又不接纳外国，可以谈吐绅士但是行为冷血，可以拥有许许多多互相矛盾的想法和行为倾向（propositional attitude）。所以说，日本人或许是矛盾的，但是其实每个人多多少少是一个矛盾体，而这个矛盾来源于我们追求理想世界的自我和受限于现实约束的自我之间的冲突。举种族歧视的例子来说，在美国生活过一段时间的人自然知道种族歧视的言论和行为是一条红线绝对不能触碰，所以说我们大都非常注意这一点，不作出任何歧视性的行为，发誓自己对所有的人种一视同仁。但是若遇上结婚这样的人生大事，相信很多人再怎么努力说服自己也无法做出种族中性的决定，而此时现实自我又怎么能向理想自我妥协呢。日本的独特之处在于这个国家有着极其严格的社会规范和高度程序化的社会秩序，在这样的一个社会中生活的人们，可想而知，其现实自我和理想自我的差距将会更大，作为一个旁观者，我们也更可能做出一个“日本人是矛盾体”的结论。

这个学期了解了很多关于日籍混血的人的故事，看了一部纪录片“ハーフ”，然后拜读了斯坦福教授Stephen Murphy-Shigematsu所著“When Half is Whole“。大部分的故事有着非常类似的剧情，日本和其他某个国家的混血，在日本土生土长，母语是日语但是得不到日本社会的接纳和认同。关于这些故事本身我没有什么特别要评论的地方，毕竟人生来就有群聚的倾向，而外表和生活习性的相似度恰恰决定了一个人融入某个特定聚群的可能性。说全世界打破这个规则的国家，除了美国估计也就只有加拿大了，可是就算在这两个国家也很难说种族外表完全不对划分聚群起到任何作用。此外，社会接纳和认同是一个非常含糊的概念，什么样的标准算是接纳和认同，是法律层面的，社交层面的还是心理层面的。很多情况下，一个人的社交资本（social capital）起到了压倒性的作用，特别是在日本这个上下尊卑关系极其分明的国家，拥有更多的社交资本必然会更加容易进入主流社会，而无法获得社会的接纳和认同不但有种族或者背景的原因，更多地或许是社交资本的匮乏。Stephen教授是日美的混血，在东京大学任教过一段时间，教的不是英语而是社会心理学方面的文科。对于他而言，虽然是ハーフ，但是日本人听了他的职位往往都会肃然起敬，他也或多或少能得到一定的社会认可。但是他最终因为“种族疲劳”（ethnic fatigue，指混血等外观上容易被认为是外国人的人，生活在自己的国家但是每时每刻被质疑种族或者国籍，需要不断解释声明而疲劳不已）还是离开了日本，这就是另一个故事了。此外，我在知乎上也看到一篇关于“生活在日本是一种什么样的感受”的文章，答主说“普通的日本人能做到三分，而我能做到五分，所以我在日本生活也没感受到什么大的不认同或者歧视”。所以说，社会对于外来者的不认同固然是每个社会的劣根性，但是要是把不认同和歧视挂在嘴边，那或许也只是弱者的借口罢了。

“When Half is Whole”当中有一个故事，是讲一个混血的男孩，小学一年级到三年级在名古屋的一所公立小学读书，在学校收到欺凌，从四年级开始转学到一家国际学校继续学习。自从转学到了国际学校，他的同学从单一的日本孩子变成了和他一样长相各异的混血儿，他也一下子变得开朗乐观起来。他常常和国际学校的同学们一起坐电车回家，在电车上围成一个圈用英语说说笑笑好不热闹。在他的日记中，他说，和他的国际学校的同学在一起，他感到了前所未有的力量和优越感（superiority），因为他可以在电车上肆无忌惮地聊天，打外国人牌（理论上日本的电车是不允许高声交谈的）。因为有和他一样的混血朋友在，他可以不用介意周围日本人的眼光，因为在这个时候，他就是一个“天生优越的外国人”，他能完全理解所有日本人在窃窃私语什么，但是他知道这些日本人完全听不懂他们之间说的英语。不过，等电车过了中转站，大家陆陆续续都下车之后，他突然发现一个人的他之前的优越感荡然无存，他又变回了那个不受待见极其自卑的孩子，坐在椅子上用书包捂着自己的脸蛋似乎费劲一切想要隐匿自己的存在。这只是个孩子啊，你会说，但是读完这段从他日记中的引文，我觉得很悲哀。似乎人的生活状态是硬币的两面，相对于周围的人，要不是优越，要不就是低劣。对于ハーフ而言，因为有过被歧视的经历，当他们抓住了提升自己力量的机会的时候，他们或许会将这个机会发挥得淋漓尽致，歧视周围的人，找回久违的优越感，但也恰恰成为了他们原本最讨厌最憎恨的人。“The victimized can also victimize.（受害者也可能成为加害人）”，这句话再正确不过了。有的时候，打着受害的旗号毫无忌惮地去加害他人，真的是正义的么？基督山伯爵或者半沢直樹的故事也好，这个混血的小男孩的作为也罢，我们其实都不免抱有同情，毕竟以牙还牙、以眼还眼，是弱者的胜利，也是我们普通人最喜闻乐见的精神鸦片。

那为什么呢？为什么我们就不能立住这枚硬币呢？“优越感”和“自卑感”之间真的就没有“不卑不亢”的中间领地么？我想说，有肯定是有，但那估计是理想自我的范畴了，对现实自我来说，任何成功失败、喜怒哀乐，都或多或少是建立在与旁人比较的基础上，而一谈到比较，似乎比到底，要不就是“优”要不就是“劣”，相等似乎不是一个令人满意的结果。世人所说的“白富美”其实不是“白、富、美”，而是“更白、更富、更美”。正是因为比周遭的人更白、更富、更美，人们才会感到优越，而就算再白、再富、再美，没有身边的人白、没有身边的人富、没有身边的人美，也是难以不感到自卑的。我们说“比上不足，比下有余”，这虽然是一个自我安慰的方法之一，但还是建立在比较的基础上，而其结局也难以让人完全满意吧。但是不比又是不可能，我虽然强烈地抑制住自己与他人比较的情绪，但是这些机制往往是无法完全关闭的，不知不觉中我们还是因比较而喜、怒、哀、乐。这或许也是人的根性矛盾之一吧，然后这也是基督教教义中的人性原罪之一（而为了解决这个问题，我们需要信仰上帝等等，这就是后话了）。

真正把这些东西写出来还是蛮需要勇气的，我虽然这么说但是也很难真正去这样做。我会想，与其像弱者一样呻吟，不如无视这些问题，为成为一个强者而努力。这或许是我真正的想法，但是我绕着弯子说了这么多又是什么呢？或许这就是“人性教育”吧（humanity）。谢谢各位看官的阅读，预知后事如何，请听下回分解。
fields.title: Life Log Vol.1 - Lost in Tokyo
fields.preface: 本文原题为“生存报告 Vol.1 (迷失东京)”。生存报告这个词其实是从Facebook好友やぁはん那里学来的，这第一期谈的就是一个暑假在日本东京学习生活的见闻。（当然，不只是生存啦）

fields.body: あけまして、おめでとうございます。 素敵な一年をしめくくり、時差のおかげで、ずいぶん長い年越しの真ん中にいるのだ。上海や東京はもう花火が打ち上げられて、新年のお祝いが都市の隅々に響いている。サンフランシスコにいる私はまだ大みそかの日の出を迎えてきた。フェイスブックで猪俣奎介くんの回顧ポストを見かけて、夏休みの思い出をそっちがいかに大切に保存しているかふっとわかる。それが今年のハイライトのひとつで実に貴重の経歴だなあ、今振り返ったら、あらためて意識したんだ。三ヶ月を渡って、六月下旬から九月中旬まで、KCP地球市民日本語学校で言語力を磨きながら、東京地方を深くまで探検したり、HPAIR（Harvard Project for Asian and International Relations）とSKIP（Silicon Valley Keio International Program）にてほぼ同じ年の大学生たちと出会って付き合ってみたりして、長いとも短いとも言えぬ「文化の旅」なのだ。もちろん、東京で考えさせられたり、思わせられたりする出来事がいっぱいあったんだ。残念なことに、簡単に言えることじゃなくて、もつれて解けにくい糸のようなものなので、日本にいる限られた時間の中でみんなとシェアしてなかった。年末のきっかけ、一ヶ月前中国語で書いた「日本から話そう」ってエッセイを日本語で書き直して、日本の皆さんと精神的に交流したいと思う。 3ヶ月日本に滞在したあとの今、この国を一言で言い表すこともできなければ、なにかエレメントを選んでこの国を代表することもできなくなった。「日本ってどんな国なの」よく友達に問われる私は、正直、どうやって答えればいいかさっぱりわからなかった。ある日、ふと思いついたまあまあの答えは、「日本はかなり矛盾している国かな」なのだった。矛盾という点は私が日本で最も感じたことだ。例をあげてみよう。通勤電車に乗るサラリーマンは例外なくみんな全く区別できない白いシャツと黒いパンツ、そのせいで、毎朝通学する私はもし鮮やかな服を着たら、目立ってちょっと不安したに決まっている（なぜそんなに人の目線を気にするか？社会からプレッシャと影響を受けて、ちょっと同化されるかも）。これによって、日本社会の高度な統一性を伺えるんじゃないか。電車の中で、飲食禁止とか、大声でしゃべるなとか、ほとんどの人は無形のルールを守って、行動が社会契約に従っているだろう。この社会契約に押された私は電車の中で常に気を揉んでいた。日本語学校に通うときはそのまま、HPAIRの時になったら、スーツを着て会場に行くことになって、とうとうホッとして、解放したんだ。「やっと、みんなと一緒になったー」、今見れば本当におかしい考えをその時にしてた。 他方では、この社会は様々な不思議なサブカルチャーを許して共存している。女子高生の制服を着るおじいさん、ロリータを夢中になる女の子、鼻や唇にネジをつけて１０センチ以上のプラットフォームブーツを履く原宿パンクやヴィジュアル系、秋葉原を始めのオタク文化など、数え切れない。当たり前の権利とはいえ、これらの人たちは公然と街を歩いて、集まって、自分のサブカルチャーをアピールすることは、高度統一の日本社会なら、信じがたいことになっても言い過ぎない。それに加え、ほかの通行人もそういうサバカルチャーをあんまり気にせず、じろじろ見詰める人は外国の旅行者に間違いない。なぜなら、もう見飽きてしまったから、なんでもいいかも。心の中にひそかに見下し、自分と彼らの間に線をはっきり描いたけど、声を絶対出さないかも。正直に言えば、日本に長く住めば住むほど、「みんなと同じになりたい」という同化を求める欲望を次第に抱いていく。この欲望はいつの間にか自分の血に溶けて、心に刻んだら、たとえ周りの言葉や顔色を気にしなくなっても、心の奥から強烈な力（自尊心であるかも）により自分の社会行為を制約する。だから、ファンファーレでサブカルチャーのはたを振る人々は、昔にみんなと同じになりたかったかもしれないが、その後、社会からの認めを得なかったり、単一の社会に対し憎みを生んだりしたから、「破れかぶれ」になって、今、社会の縛りを潰して遠慮無く自分の個性をあらわすところに歩んできたんろう。 これ以上は矛盾の一つである。ほかの矛盾といえば、中国人よりもっと西洋を憧れている日本人は日本社会の周りに石垣を立てて外国人は無論で、日本で生まれ育ったハーフだって完全に受け入れないこと。恥ずかしくて控えめな日本人は、空気を読みながら言葉に気を配ったり、礼義にこだわったりするのに対し、日本は学校のいじめ問題が深刻で、第二次世界大戦のとき、ひどく非人道的なことをやったことがある国であること。そのように、矛盾の点が数多いんじゃないだろうか。 ここまで書いたら、私はちょっと心配することがある。国は矛盾のものだと言うより、この、全国にわたって一億以上の人々の行為を大まかに一般化する考え方は、矛盾が起きるゆえんだと言ったほうがいい。もっと考えれば、多くの時に矛盾しているのは一つの民族じゃなくて、ただ一人一人だと考えられる。人とは、本来から、他人と同じにしたい同時に自分の異なる個性を保ちたいし、外国に憧れながらも外国のことを認めることができないし、紳士的な態度の裏に冷たいこころがいるし、多くの矛盾した考えと行為を同時に持っている謎の生き物ということだ。日本人は矛盾した民族かもしれないが、この世の中に全ての人は矛盾したものだと言ったらもっとふさわしいと思う。矛盾があることが人類に共通してる理由は、私たちの中に、理想的な世界を追いかける「われ」が現実に縛られる「われ」と厳しく戦っているからだと信じている。人種差別の例から考えてみよう。アメリカに少しだけ住んだ経験がある人は、人種差別の言葉と行為をするのが高圧送電線を触るような、絶対できないことだと知っているから、みんなその点に特別に注意するよね。人種によらず、みんなを平等な目で見ると誓っている。それにもかかわらず、結婚など大きな決定をするとき、私を含めて、何度自分を説得しても、人種を無視することができなくて、理想のわれが現実のわれと妥協してしまった人がたくさんいるんじゃないだろうか。それで、厳しい規則と固い秩序に支配される日本社会で奮闘する人々は、言うに及ばず、理想のわれと現実のわれの距離が大きすぎるからこそ、バイスタンダードとしての私は「日本人が矛盾である」という結論を下してしまっただろう。 終わったばかりの秋学期、「ハーフ」というドキュメンタリーを見たり、元東大の教授でいまスタンフォードの教授のスティーブン・マーフィー重松先生の著作「When Half is Whole」を拝見したりするに通して、在日ハーフの生活を知り始めた。話の内容は、たぶん皆さんの推測どおり、日本に生まれて育ったハーフが、母国語が日本語だが、社会から認められないという。これについて、別にコメントしたいことがない。けっきょく、人は群がる傾向が強い。外見や生活の習慣によって誰が誰と群がるか決めるのは人類の本能である。この本能を破った国は、アメリカ以外に、たぶんカナダしかない。しかし、この二つの国の中に、人種や民族によって人が群がる場合はないとは言えない。ところで、社会からの認めはけっこう曖昧なコンセプトだが、どのようになれば社会から認めたと言えるなの？法律的、社会的、それとも、心理的なの。多くの場合、圧倒的に役を立てるものは人のソーシャル・キャピタル（社会関係資本）なのだ。特に上下関係が厳しい日本には、もっとソーシャル・キャピタルを持っていれば、社会主流に入れやすいかもしれない。逆に、人種や背景より、ソーシャル・キャピタルなしのほうが、人が社会に認めてもらえない理由になる（悲しいことに、このような悪循環になってしまう可能性がある）。スティーブン先生は日本とアメリカのハーフなのに、東大で英語じゃなくて社会心理学を教えているという、誰かにとっても尊敬すべきで素晴らしい仕事をしていたから、多少日本社会に認めてもらえたんだ。ただし、先生は最後に「エスニック疲労」（ethnic fatigue、ハーフなど外観にしてみると外国人と見間違いがちな人が、毎日毎日自分の国籍や民族を問われて、説明せざるを得ないせいで、疲れて我慢できなくなる現象を指す）のため日本を去ってアメリカに戻った（これは別の話）。だから、外から来た人を認めないのは社会の原罪だと言えるものの、「認められない！」とか「差別されたんだ！」とか、もしいつもそんな文句を言ってばかりいったら、つい言い訳の殻の下に生きていく弱虫になるしかない。 最後に、「When Half is Whole」にある話。ハーフの男の子、小一から小三まで名古屋の市立学校に通った間に、ときどきいじめられていたから、小四から国際の小学校に転校することにした。転校して初めて、周りの子は、全ての日本人のこどもの代わりに、顔や髪色がすべて異なる世界中のこどもになった。いじめがなくなって、目立たなくなって、この男の子は明るくて元気になりつつあった。帰宅途中でいつも国際学校のハーフ友達と一緒にグループとして電車を乗る。電車の中に、子たちは円陣を組んで、英語で話し合って盛り上がっていく。男の子のダイアリーによると、ハーフ何人と一緒に電車に乗るなら、以前一回とも感じたことがない力と優位性を感じたそうだ。一人じゃないから、自分の外国人の外観に乗って、周りの日本人の視線を一切忘れて、どんな大きな声でも、話たいだけ話せるそうだ。今の僕は生まれつき優位な外国人だから、周りの人は蚊の鳴くような声でささやいても僕がわかるけれども、僕たちはどんな大きな声で叫んでも彼らはさっぱりわからないそうだ！しかしながら、いくつ乗り換え駅を通って、その男の子が一人の状態に戻ってしまったとたん、前の優位性をパッと失って、自分の存在を隠そうとするために、顔を膝に乗せたランドセルに埋めて、もともと自尊心の弱すぎるその子に戻らされてしまった。 「彼はただこどもなんだ！」それはそうだけど、私は彼を評価したいわけじゃなくて、ただこの話を読んだら、悲しい気持ちが満たされた。まるで、人が周りの人との扱い方は、コインの裏表のような、２種類にすぎない。他人より優位（superority）、他人より劣位（inferority）、この二つだけ。ハーフにとって、差別される経験があったから、もし自分の力や地位をあげる機会をつかめば、人を差別したり、優位性を奪い戻したりし、この機会をお返しにして、いかんなく利用することにしてしまう。知らず知らずのうちに、彼らは自分が最も嫌いな人間になりきった。“The victimized can also victimize.（傷つかれた人も人を傷つける）”、これ以上正しい言葉がない。ときどき、傷つかれたことがあるという理由で人を傷つく、それは本当に正義的なのか？モンテ・クリスト伯という小説もあれば、半沢直樹というテレビドラマもある（「やられたら、やり返す。倍返した！」を言い換えれば、「傷つかれた人も人を傷つける」になるんじゃないか）。これらの人たちに同情をそそるのは人の善なのか、なにしろこれらの「目には目を、歯には歯を」の物語は、弱者の勝利であり、我々普通にすぎない人々の精神的なマリファナであると思っている。 なぜ？なぜ私たちはこのコインを立てないの？優位と劣位の間に何もないの？あるよ！って言おうとしたいけれども、それは理想われの範囲なので、現実われで言えば、成功、失敗、喜び、悲しみ、どんな気持ちでも、いくらか周りの人との比較のうえに築いているのだ。比較といえば、最後まで、かならず勝負が出る。その勝負が、優位、または劣位にしかない。引き分けが人を満足させられない。かわいい顔とか、金持ちとか、実は人を幸せにさせられない。人を幸せにさせるのは、「周りの人よりかわいい」、「周りの人より金持ち」なんだ！たとえ、顔がどんなに可愛くても、お金がどんなにたくさんあっても、周りの人と比べて、可愛くない、お金少ないとしたら、相変わらず悲しくになりかねない。中国語なら、「上には劣るが、下には優る」ということわざがある。これは確かに自分をなぐさめるいい方法なのに、まだ比較と離れていないから、いい結果になれるかどうかわからない。私は、いつも他人と比べたい気持ちを抑えているけど、思わず人と比べてしまったら、自分が気分を変えたときがたくさんある。いくつ段落のさっきで書いてあるように、これは人間が変えれない生まれつきの矛盾なのだろう（この問題の解決方法なら、宗教にあるかも）。 めっちゃ真剣な話なので、ここまで読んでくれれば嬉しい。もし、感想とかコメントとかがあったら、お気軽に私と話し合ってください。そして、言語に関わる間違いは、先にあやまっておく。できれば、指摘してください。 それでは、改めて、あけましておめでとう！２０１５年も、よろしくお願いします！
fields.title: Happy Half New Year

fields.body:
I woke up, in the midst of a gloomy and damp tunnel. Shafts of light could barely reach my eyes from its very far end but they beckoned to my instincts without any extra effort. I crawled towards the opening, curious about any possibility that lies beyond the darkness. Once I finally stuck my head out, a grandeur chamber that glitters with gold ornaments and saturates in blinding lights astounded me. I could see thousands of creatures with similar appearances to mine emerging from countless outlets around the chamber, convening into groups, converging into threads, all climbing in uniform direction towards the podium erecting in the grand center. An omnipotent figure, surrounded by his impeccable aura, is drawing some colored pebble form a gigantic urn that stands on top of the podium. Red, white, white, red, white, white, white… I was counting the color of all the pebbles that were drawn from the urn when waiting in line for my own trial. People who won a red pebble are welcomed to enter an elevator that pierces through the roof from which all lights are pouring in, while everyone else who received a white pebble are instructed to enter another dimly lighted tunnel that leads to some remote destination. “I might bet my destiny on that draw”, I whispered to myself as the line slowly moves close to the podium. I was too fearful to conceive which destiny was going to befall. So I closed my eyes.

Some are born to sweet delight; others to endless night.[REF *= Blake, William. Auguries of innocence. Printed anew for Grossman Publishers, 1968.]

It is a disheartened human consensus that people are never born to the same starting line. People are born into families with different social-economical status, born with different body shapes, skin colors or facial appearances, and also born into different bounded sovereign political entities. As Ayelet Shachar, professor of law at University of Toronto, succinctly puts it, people are born with their own “birthright lottery” [REF *= Shachar, Ayelet. The birthright lottery: citizenship and global inequality. Harvard University Press, 2009.]. To the negative side, just because this is such a stark reality that no one could subvert, everyone resides on its fate and prospers in its own way. To the positive side, modern society is steadily becoming more embracing and equal towards differences stemmed from biological factors. Social norms against discrimination based on race, gender, physical attractiveness, etc., are our endeavors to mitigate the effect imposed by birthright lottery. There are also a series of government enforced taxes and subsidies that relieve social inequality in a more substantial way.

People who cease to struggle with birthright lottery and instead accept the status quo are most likely overcome by the immutability of birth-time circumstances regulated by the nature. Within the current context of science and technology, intelligence, appearance, even talents are preset and therefore immutable. It is not meaningful to wrestle with the nature and if we insist, we will learn the same lesson in a hard way. Nevertheless, lots of people are ignorant of one particular part of the birthright lottery that seems to but is actually not immutable to the extent of the rigidity nature holds. Birthright citizenship, shielded among other innate properties, is usually justified as the natural rights a sovereign country entitles to its newborn citizens. People are educated to perceive the immutability and arbitrary distribution of birthright citizenship as legitimate (this is true) and morally axiomatic (this is false). In fact, the endowment of citizenship at birth time is totally contingent upon the discretion of any individual state, in other words, some institutions that are totally manmade, reflects the values of a certain group of people, and stands at the diametric opposite of any nature decider.[REF *= Carens, Joseph. The ethics of immigration. Oxford University Press, 2013.] Therefore, we can and should question the naturalness of birthright citizenship that builds upon the conventional laws that entitled sovereign states to decide whom they want as their citizens and whom they do not want.[REF *= Carens, Joseph. The ethics of immigration. Oxford University Press, 2013.]

<hr>

Before I tweak your intuition to accept citizenship de-naturalized, let us explore several reasons that ordinary people like you and me are not so aware of birthright citizenship as one major component in the birthright lottery that brings about inequality. First of all, citizenship might be confused with other immutable traits as suggested in the previous paragraph. The key here is that, citizenship is almost immutable (97% of the global population that has been holding the citizenship that was granted at birth time throughout the entire life[REF *= Global Commission on International Migration. Migration in an interconnected world: new directions for action. The Commission, 2005.]) in the framework of current immigration laws and international protocols, but it is not immutable in the sense that one’s skin tone is immutable under biological determinism.

Second, we do not really understand what citizenship is, or oversimplified its definition. We might equate it to the rights to vote, the rights to enroll in public schools, the sense of mutual belongings and other civic rights and responsibilities.[REF *= Shachar, Ayelet. The birthright lottery: citizenship and global inequality. Harvard University Press, 2009.] What about the rights to remain in the territory, the rights to clean water and sufficient food, or international mobility? We would never understand the entire scope of citizenship as long as we live inside the boarders and only compare us with our peers. In fact, if we only concern whatever inside the boarders, we no longer need the term citizenship itself, as everyone is included and everyone has the same bundle of rights. It is precisely because this polarized world has everything in disparity and inequality, the scope of citizenship is vast so as to distinguish some right entitled by one citizenship but devoid in another citizenship. Unfortunately, we are not able to witness all these disparities, and thus have a narrower interpretation of what citizenship entails.

Thirdly, and the most importantly, we lack an intuitive understanding of the role citizenship plays in deciding one individual’s life trajectory and perpetuating global inequality. Once these intuitions are evoked, no matter how self-righteous governments’ propagandas on citizenship and immigration are, they can not camouflage the true unnaturalness of birthright citizenship. Regarding establishing intuition of object values, people usually carry out an explicit monetary appraisal or compare the objects in question to other more familiar things. You might find both of these two approaches quite challenging in the context of citizenship, so bear with me to the discoveries of both a monetary evaluation and a tangible analogy of birthright citizenship. Until then, it is up to you deciding if the imperative to ameliorate the current birthright citizenship endowment system is somehow necessary.

<hr>

The analogy of citizenship lies behind citizenship’s intended functionality. These intensions tend to be fuzzy when inspected under specific scenarios, say naturalization. Professor Joseph Carens, in his book The Ethics of Immigration, presents the common-ground criteria to be qualified for naturalization as “having established membership within a specific society” [REF *= Carens, Joseph. The ethics of immigration. Oxford University Press, 2013.]. This membership can be established by working status, long-term residence, marriage and all other sorts of ways. Nevertheless, immigrants have to prove any of these in order to get the testimony, namely, a citizenship certificate. On the other hand, newborn infants who are granted citizenship solely based on birthplace or descents have nothing to prove their established membership. It is merely a promising future that they will establish their membership in the target society that qualifies them to be granted the certificate in advance. This does not sound fair, does it?

So the set of common-ground criteria for naturalization is actually a chicken-or-the-egg dilemma that fails to manifest the real intention of citizenship. Then what is the real intention if there is one? We have to examine from a macroscopic viewpoint. Ayelet Shachar proposes an argument that draws citizenship in analogy with inheritance, when viewing one country as a whole. In light of her theory, citizenship is like a property that has been inherited from a certain population to its progenies by either descents or any arbitrary standard the former group articulates[REF *= Shachar, Ayelet. The birthright lottery: citizenship and global inequality. Harvard University Press, 2009.]. This scheme allows the privileged to pass down the privilege to a selected group within their control and debar the unprivileged from interfering or stealing their established privilege.

[IMG *= privilege-pool.jpg 80%]

Based on her inheritance theory, I would like to introduce a privilege pool model that further illustrates the gate-keeping and opportunity-distribution[REF *= Held, David. Between State and Civil Society: Citizenship. London: Lawrence & Wishart, 1991.] functionality that citizenship has. Consider country borders demarcate the global resources and each country remains to have its sovereign control over anything within its borders. Whether it is tangible recourses like water, clean environment, public health, or intangible ones like political stability, community safety, economic robustness, you name it, they can all be aggregated to a privilege pool that is managed as well as consumed by the population residing within the borders. The privilege pool is in a dynamic equilibrium where people who passed away return their accessible rights to the privileges back to the pool and these returned values as well as any surplus generated by current lease holders (citizens) are re-distributed to the newborn or any alien immigrant that the state believes to be capable of bringing in positive privilege inflow. If everything is regulated under the supervision of state, the privilege pool system can be shut close to the outer world and self-sustained so that no privilege will leak out unnecessarily. And this is unmistakably the current practice of countries with higher volume of privilege: simply shutting tight all valves and only distribute and redistribute within the system boundary.

<hr>

Does the privilege pool model sound familiar to you? Maybe. If you are familiar with medieval feudalism, you will find its shadow there. In feudalism, different social class is a self-contained privilege pool and little privilege would be shared unless a person is born into the right social class[REF *= Brown, Elizabeth A.R. Feudalism. Encyclopedia Britannica, 2014. http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/205583/feudalism/]. How deplorable it is when we just realize that centuries of social advancement has not lifted humanity out of draconic laws that guard the privilege pools, and the current citizenship system is no better than the feudalism and even worse if compared with scale of influence.

Well, if this is the reality, then let us doff all of its remaining camouflages and reveal its stark nature. If every country is a privilege pool, how huge is it, respectively? And if the redistribution functionality grants a “birth package” to the newborn, how much is that? On earth, how much in terms of privilege a baby born into a developed country is granted compared to his or her counterpart born into a developing country’s?

I aggregated data of 174 different countries from Human Development Index[REF *= United Nations Development Program. Human Development Index. 2014.], Environmental Performance Index[REF *= Yale Center for Environmental Law & Policy (YCELP), the Center for International Earth Science Information Network (CIESIN) at Columbia University. Environmental Performance Index. 2014.] and World Bank Database[REF *= The World Bank. World Bank Open Data. 2014. http://data.worldbank.org/]. The value of birth package is calculated from a particular country’s average life expectancy, gross national income per capita (in purchasing power parity to offset various living costs), social inequality index (Gini coefficient[REF *= Gini coefficient. Wikipedia. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gini_coefficient/]), and environmental health index. The basic rationale behind is that, regardless of variations from person to person, the birth package should reflect the minimal resources that have been granted to one individual in both tangible and intangible forms. Given that a comprehensive enumeration of all possible forms is not quite feasible, I take an alternative approach by measuring the output of these resources, namely, the minimal life performance slash quality of an average citizen representative. To keep the calculation simple and avoid double counting, I do not factor in indexes on education (it has already been reflected by income), government corruption (this is hardly correlated), and other nitty-gritty aspects. For the actual formula and all mathematical details, feel free to refer to the appendix.

[IMG *= package-population-diagram.png]

The above figure delineates the results, where the horizontal axis represents the percentage of global population and the vertical axis represents the size of birth package in unit of $1,000. You might expect a significant gap between sizes of birth package at the most developed countries and the least developed countries. In fact, the gap is tremendously significant. Just to mention a few, the global average size of birth package weighted by population is US$ 290,759. Norway, at the leading top of the chart, has a birth package size of US$ 3,006,542. United States, despite its internal social inequality and extreme heterogeneity, has a universal birth package size of US$ 1,135,012. In contrast, near the bottom of the chart, Democratic Republic of Congo has birth package of merely US$ 1,615, which is scarcely 1 over 1862 of the size of Norway. In such a world where a baby born into the most affluent country is almost two-thousand times richer than one into the most destitute country just at birth time, do you feel a little bit lucky now that you happen to be born in the right country? I hope so. In fact, the possibility that a person is born into a country that gives out birth package that worth more than the world average is not 50%, but a shockingly 22.3%. In other words, the privileges are largely slanted towards the top quarter of the global population even at the deprival of the bottom quartile of their basic life needs and human rights.

<hr>

So, what is the solution? Scholars provide a wide range of options from abolishing international boarders, resurrecting boarders, commodifying citizenship, taxing inherited birthright citizenship, so on and so forth[REF *= Shachar, Ayelet. The birthright lottery: citizenship and global inequality. Harvard University Press, 2009.]. None of them seems to be a panacea and some even lead to construction of a utopia or dystopia. A synergy of different solutions might help, but it largely relies on the public’s mutual understanding of birthright citizenship as a main perpetuator of global inequality and followed willingness to relinquish part of their privileges out of moral urges.

It might be claimed that citizens should be able to regulate immigration as necessary to protect their freedom, welfare, and culture[REF *= Fiala, Andrew, ed. The Bloomsbury Companion to Political Philosophy.Bloomsbury Publishing, 2015.]. But as far as we should concern now, states have more a prima facie duty to maintain relatively open boarders. And this is not enough, because international mobility even with open borders is still financially unfeasible to the population at the pyramid bottom. Moreover, this approach is only a palliative that can never tremendously increase the living standards of those impoverished countries. The privilege pool remains depleted, the birth package remains thin and the inequality persists.

Therefore, others practice like taxation should supplement. As a classic method to regulate intra-society inequality, it could also be deployed to mitigate inter-society inequality. For countries that have a birth package with above-average value, the government, if required by international protocol, should pay a certain percentage value as “citizenship tax”. The collected tax will be channeled to countries in need and help them with basic infrastructures, education, and eventually ignite their own value-generating engines. Based on my data collection, the “citizenship tax/subsidy” per capita per year is calculated from the birth package size, birth rate, and a flat tax rate 40%[REF *= Bell, Key. Estate tax and gift tax amounts. Bankrate.com, 2015.] (similarly, refer to the appendix for details). Under my calculations, every US citizen is required to pay US$ 4,532 (8.7% of gross national income per capita) as a levy for its privileged citizenship rights. And every citizen of Democratic Republic of Congo will receive US$ 4,120 as a remedy for its dire living circumstances. This looks promising but it is still far from a possible international consensus and I am not totally confident that moral scruples could overcome people’s selfishness and indifference. Let alone there will be a huge deficit (around US$ 4.63 trillion) if the international community actually practices taxation and subsidization as suggests above.

<hr>

Solutions are still far from any of us. However, the general awareness of what citizenship entitles, how much it worth and how resources are distributed unequally under its name, is definitely a plus to humanity. I hope the numbers I just showed you might occur to you the next time you cast a vote, enjoy one day of community peace, or travel internationally. I hope they would not fear you or scare you, but empower you with a more intuitive appreciation of your own privilege and the rights you are exercising. 

Some are born to sweet delight; others to endless night. When we fully denaturalized the birthright citizenship, we start to realize that neither do we deserve our privileged birth package, nor does anyone have the rights to claim that he or she deserves it. This a paradox: you have to admit to the reality but at the same time you must refrain from taking it for granted.  But thanks to this double thinking, we learned to be appreciative and sympathetic. Right now, as we cannot immediately alter the way the pebble is drawn from the urn, let us close our eyes and say thank you, to that red peddle gripped in our hands, and to everyone who is lining behind us that witnessed our triumph at our birthright lottery.

今日は、日本の伝統武道に関して、紹介させていただこうと思います。「日本」と言えば、みなさんの頭にすぐ思い浮かぶことはなんでしょう。口に入れたとたん溶けてしまうほど新鮮なトロすしか、ネオンが競い輝いている新宿三丁目の街並みか、それとも、裸と裸がぶつかり合う相撲なのか。私のように、相撲を日本の代名詞にする人が数多くいるんじゃないでしょうか。国技と認められている相撲の魅力と文化的な大切さが、相撲と日本の密接なつながりをきちんと裏付けているのです。

相撲は、「現代武道」と分類されるにもかかわらず、歴史が昔に遡れます。奈良時代（８世紀）のころ宮廷で行事や余興として行われていたあと、次の平安時代の三百年の間に宮廷儀式の「すまいのせち」の開催に伴って、どんどん武道の形に発展を遂げました。さらに、江戸時代（１７−１９世紀）のころ、職業としての相撲が盛んになり、現在の「日本相撲協会」の元のプロ相撲、いわゆる「大相撲」の競技もそれから生まれました。

他の競技と比べて、相撲の規則はとても簡単です。ただ一つ注意すべきことは、伝統的な競技である相撲に対して使う言葉もけっこう古くて、西洋競技の言葉と全く違うということです。理解しやすいように、ボクシングの用語で相撲のルールを表すとしたら、「二人の選手がリングで戦い、先に相手を倒したり、またはリングの外に出したりできる選手は試合に勝つ」になります。それに相撲の言葉を当てはめると、「二人の力士が土俵で素手と回し1枚の状態で戦い、先に相手を倒したり、または土俵の外に出したりできる力士は取組に勝つ」になるはずです。一つの取組はわずか数秒から、数分間に至るまでに終わるけれども、勝負が出る瞬間は本当にまばたきするほど短いです。互角に戦う時のテンションが人を土俵に釘付けにさせることもあれば、あっという間に見事な「決まり手」が勝負を分けて、観客を驚かせることもあるから、大勢の人が相撲に夢中になるのは不思議なことではありません。

みんなが相撲を楽しめるその一方で、プロ相撲の力士になるのはかなり難しいです。この道を選んだ人は必ず「部屋」という相撲の塾に加入して、一番下の順位、相撲用語で「序ノ口」という番付から長い修行を始めます。この「序ノ口」とは、ただ相撲の入口に立つということで、このあたりの番付を持つ力士は毎日稽古に取り組んでいるのみならず、自分より上級の力士に胸を借りたり、掃除や食事準備などの雑用をしたりしなければなりません。きびしい練習に練習を重ねて、力士たちは技、運と精神力を全部賭けて、２か月ごとの全国試合「本場所」に挑んでいます。１５日にわたる本場所で半分以上の取組を勝ち抜ければ、上の番付に昇進する可能性があります。序二段から、三段目、幕下、十両、前頭、小結、関脇、大関、一歩一歩ついに横綱まで、ピラミッドの頂点を極められる力士は一握りに過ぎないから、横綱の名は不動のものにして全国から注目を浴びるのは当たり前です。

ある意味で、国技と言われる相撲は日本社会の鏡だといっても過言ではないです。神道に従い、儀式にこだわり、品格を培い、そして上下関係を厳重に守る大相撲はまるで小さい社会のようです。なお一層、大相撲の番付を一生懸命に登り続けて、序ノ口から、幕内に入って、大関、横綱にさえ行ける力士の経過は、普通の会社員から障害を一つずつ崩して常務まで昇進した半沢直樹と、秋葉原の一人もいない劇場から満席の国立競技場まで進んできたAKB48と、あまり差異がないんじゃないでしょうか。勝負や昇進などは決して相撲の全てじゃないものの、相撲力士が本場所を勝ち抜いて、ますます番付を上げる筋書きの無いドラマは、この残酷な縦社会の中で奮闘している人間に勇気と励ましを送っているから、相撲は甚大な社会影響を及ぼすことができると思います。

日本の伝統と文化のエッセンスを携える相撲は最近多様化しています。アマチュアとして相撲をする人がよく見られるし、相撲に励む女性も増えているし、アジアや欧米などの外国で相撲ファンが多くなっているから、「相撲」この日本武道は、他の伝統と比較して途絶えかねないどころか、これからももっと人気が集まり、オリンピックに入って、世界中で輝いていくのも夢ではないでしょう。

fields.body:
An articulation of the criterion to preclude an agent’s moral responsibility is essential to answering the compatibility problem of determinism and free will. Once the criterion is settled, we can examine if determinism entails this criterion so as to resolve if determinism is compatible or incompatible with free will that suffices moral responsibility. Harry Frankfurt and Derk Pereboom ended up with opposing answers to the compatibility problem in light of their thought experiments, primarily due to their disagreement about the abovementioned criterion. Harry Frankfurt disproves the efficacy of the criterion that an agent being not able to have done otherwise precludes its moral responsibility (I denote this criterion as Lack of Alternate Possibilities Criterion, or simply LAP) and suggests a compatibilist view. Derk Pereboom, on the other hand, demonstrates the criterion that an agent’s action being the product of a deterministic process outside its control precludes its moral responsibility (I denote this criterion as Deterministic Process Criterion, or simply DP) and then defenses his hard determinist (incompatibilist) stance. This paper will first discuss the thought experiments employed by both philosophers as means of argumentation and then analyze the battleground of the clashing theories introduced by these thought experiments.

In Harry Frankfurt’s “Alternate Possibilities and Moral Responsibility”, he conceives of a person Jones<sub>4</sub> who might perform a certain action. He also conceives of another figure Black who wants Jones<sub>4</sub> to perform that exact action. Black does not interfere with Jones<sub>4</sub>’s internal rationale unless Jones<sub>4</sub> is detected to have any inkling of thoughts that might lead to his not performing the action. In that case, Black will take effective steps to ensure that Jones<sub>4</sub> will actually perform his desired action. However, it turns out that Jones<sub>4</sub> initially prefers to perform that action, even if the potential interference imposed by Black does not exist. Jones<sub>4</sub>’s decision to perform the action, out of his own reasons, necessitates he being morally responsible, despite he could not have done otherwise (even could not choose otherwise) under the leverage of Black. Frankfurt elaborately designs this experiment to be dissectible. When considering whether Jones<sub>4</sub> should be held morally responsible, we consider his rationale and intention in absence of Black’s external intervention. Conversely, when considering if Jones<sub>4</sub>’s circumstances satisfy LAP, Black’s external intervention overshadows the efficacy of Jones<sub>4</sub>’s internal propensity. After both parts are intuitively accepted, Frankfurt has succeeded in convincing us that LAP is actually compatible with moral responsibility because Jones<sub>4</sub> is just a cogent example where someone bears moral responsibility even though not able to have done otherwise. Though not evident in Frankfurt’s text, he seems also to claim that under the premise that LAP is all that determinism entails, compatibility of determinism with moral responsibility logically follows from compatibility of LAP with moral responsibility.

Derk Pereboom, in response to Frankfurt’s theory, acknowledges his strong and resilient thought experiment for building a compatible view between moral responsibility and LAP. However, as a hard determinist, he refuses to compromise on compatibility between moral responsibility and DP or hard determinism. The thought experience he uses is a series of four scenarios in which an imaged character Mr. Green committed a murder. The four scenarios are similar in the sense that they all try to offer an explanation for Green’s motivation but they are configured in such a way that the explanation transits from more specific and imaginary ones gradually to more general and realistic ones. In Case 1, Green is created and manipulated by neuroscientists to commit the murder. In Case 2, instead of direct manipulation, neuroscientists have programmed him at birth as a rational egoist, which eventually leads to the murder. In Case 3, instead of fictional neuroscientists, the rigorous milieu where he grew up determined him to be a rational egoist, which eventually leads to the murder. In the final Case 4, instead of instantiating a particular deterministic factor, it directly supposes the truth of physicalist determinism, because of which Green is rationally egoistic and eventually commits the murder. The last case corresponds to DP where one person’s action is causally determined by factors beyond its control.

It would be much harder to convince the readers the lack of moral responsibility in the last scenario were the first three cases not provided as sub-steps. The absurdity of direct neural manipulation in Case 1 intuitively eliminates moral responsibility of the subject. Once the obvious case is accepted, Pereboom pushes readers bit by bit through more obscure cases. The difference delta between any two adjacent cases is controlled to be not qualitative but only quantitative because a quantitative alternation seems to be unprincipled to flip our previous intuition. For example, from Case 1 to Case 2, only the length of the temporal interval between the programming and the action is extended, and Pereboom persuades us that this extension is irrelevant to the moral responsibility in question; therefore, Green is not morally responsible in Case 2 the same as what we believed in Case 1. Just because Pereboom pays careful attention to controlling the gap between adjacent cases so that every step is small enough to be intuitively continuous and conceivable, once we reach the final case along the given route, we are almost certain that DP precludes moral responsibility that Green should be excused since his action results from a deterministic causal process that traces back to factors beyond his control. This conclusion might seem to be counter-intuitive when we scrutinize our ordinary moral judgments. Pereboom crisply rejects this intuition by arguing its wrong basis, in particular denial or negligence of determinism. Self proposed objection and rejoinder like this further reinforce the hard determinism arguments of Pereboom.

As effectively shown by Frankfurt and Pereboom by thought experiments, we regard it true that DP precludes moral responsibility while LAP fails to do so. Despite my appreciation for both of the thought experiments, I am unsatisfied by the ambiguity when Frankfurt attempts to advance from the compatibilism argument about LAP and moral responsibility to the compatibilism argument about determinism and moral responsibility. I am inclined to agree with Pereboom because his arguments built upon the criterion of DP sounds more like what determinism actually means. As pointed out in his objection to Frankfurt, determinism implies the stronger criterion DP and the weaker criterion LAP in the sense that the stronger criterion DP is a sufficient and necessary condition for determinism while the weaker criterion LAP does not imply determinism in this reverse direction. Frankfurt shows that when people bear moral responsibility, LAP can hold. But according to Pereboom, LAP does not imply determinism so that determinism does not have to hold in this case. And in fact, we can interpret the case of Jones<sub>4</sub> in a way so that exactly LAP holds but determinism does not hold. Jones<sub>4</sub> is not able to have done otherwise under the potential control of Black but he could have his free personal intention that is not causally determined that just happens to coincide with Black’s intention. Were Jones<sub>4</sub>’s intention and internal rationale causally determined, he would satisfy the criterion of DP and be exempt from moral responsibility as stated by Pereboom, but this is not specified in the original configuration of the thought experiment. Therefore, Frankfurt’s thought experiment of Jones<sub>4</sub> does not undermine the hard determinist view of Pereboom.

On top of the objection by Pereboom to Frankfurt, let us further consider the relationship between determinism and the criterion to rule out an agent’s moral responsibility. Frankfurt, after refuting LAP as an effective criterion, proceeds to claim that an agent is not morally responsible if he did what he did only because he was unable to do otherwise. This criterion  (denoted as only-LAP might as well) aligns with DP of Pereboom as two distinctive criteria for the preclusion of moral responsibility. Obviously, the coexistence of two criteria for a single property complicates the judging process. Hence I would like to propose a unified criterion for the property in question that can be compatible with both only-LAP of Frankfurt and DP of Pereboom. I claim that an agent is exempt from moral responsibility if all the factors that constitute its rationale for its behavior is external to its control (I name this criterion as External Rationale Criterion, or simply ER). Consider DP of Pereboom, if an agent’s action is the product of a deterministic chain beyond its control, then all the factors that constitute its rationale must be causally determined and thus external to its control. Therefore, DP implies ER. Then let us consider only-LAP of Frankfurt. The causes to a subject’s action consist of personal intentions and external constraints. The reason that Jones<sub>4</sub> is morally responsible is that he does not behave only under external compulsion; there exists some portion of the causes that is internal and subjective to him. For that reason, if only-LAP holds for some subject, that subject lacks internal intention and is fully compelled by external compulsion beyond its control. That is to say that only-LAP implies ER.

[IMG *= P2D2_D1.jpg 250px]

Now, we have the sole criterion ER to preclude an agent’s moral responsibility. The compatibility problem between determinism and free will that suffices moral responsibility boils down to the satisfiability problem of ER in the context of determinism. Pereboom, as a hard determinist, regards that determinism necessitates DP, which necessitates ER and thus determinism is incompatible with moral responsibility. On the contrary, Frankfurt mentions in his “Freedom of the Will and the Concept of a Person” that it is conceivable that a person’s ability to have free will is casually determined and in whichever case determinism is irrelevant to the satisfiability of ER. So, determinism can be compatible with free will. As far as we concern, the fundamental divergence between Frankfurt and Pereboom, as well as many other philosophers, might not lie in the criterion to preclude an agent’s moral responsibility as long as we can find a universal template to reconcile differently configured criteria. It is more dependent upon their different hypotheses of the significance of determinism and what it actually entails. Furthermore, determinism is neither unanimously agreed to cause the lack of moral responsibility, nor is its only possible cause, for the reason that there might be many other circumstances unrelated to determinism that can satisfy ER, for example, only-LAP, as we proved in the previous paragraph. On that account, it seems that given the elaborate argumentations of Frankfurt and Pereboom, the compatibility question between determinism and moral responsibility is still far from the ultimate answer, or the ultimate answer simply does not exist.
fields.title: Determinism and Moral Responsiblity
fields.preface: Whether determinism is compatible with moral responsibility is a central question for the philosophy of free will. In common-sense interpretation, determinism means a person's behaviors are decided by some factors beyond himself (like he is coerced to kill someone) and determinism usually exempts a person from moral responsibility (his penalty is far less than that of an intentional murderer because he committed the crime in opposed to his own free will). However, the actual philosophical debates between determinism and moral responsibility extend beyond where one's intuition can easily reach. This essay analyzes contradictory views of two famous philosophers Harry Frankfurt and Derk Pereboom on this topic.

「出身はどこですか？」これはごく普通の質問だと思いますが、何かその裏に隠されていることがあるのではないか、私はそう思うのです。

出身を聞けば、人々はさまざまなグループに分けられてしまいます。この分類は何か意図してやっているわけではなく、ただ潜在意識で人につけてしまう、商品特徴を表し包装に貼ってある札のような、「タグ」なのです。そのまま、人は見えないタグがつけられてしまうと、自分の外観や性格だけではなく、属しているグループに対して持っている既成概念で評価されてしまいます。皆さんが知っている文法「らしくない」、例えば、「女の子らしくない」、「日本人らしくない」のように、何か違うところがある人は既成概念と比べて評価して、その範囲から外れれば、「らしくない」と表現してしまいます。このような人間にタグをつけがちな傾向はこの世の中に根深く存在するといっても過言ではありません。

私は生まれ育った中国の上海から、アメリカに留学し、今日本で日本語を勉強中ですが、出身の質問があまり好きではありません。それはタグをつけられたくないからです。また、率直に言って、出身は私たちが決められることではなく、単純で絶対的な運であり、神様からいただいたプレゼントに過ぎないからこそ、出身の質問に深く意味があることはありえません。つまり、聞かなくてもいいです。

しかし、聞かざるを得ない場合も多くあります。実は、中国人として、日本に来るためのビザの手続きはとても複雑でした。一つ理由を言えば、中国からの不法移民が少なくないそうです。不法移民は、違法で社会に憎まれるにもかかわらず、私は、彼らを憎むどころか、感心しています。見方を変えたら、移民法は豊かな生活を送っている人たちが自分の特権を守るために、運悪く貧しいところに生活している人に対して使う武器だと思います。その一方、どんなにつらい生活を我慢しても、何度も差別されても、泣きながら新しい人生を切り開いてきた人間は偉い！彼らは、この不公平な世界と、自分の低い出身と懸命に戦っているのです。そうです。出身は運で決まるのです。ですから、高い出身を誇ったり、低い出身でも上に登りたい人を批判したりする、そのような行為に根拠は一つもないのではないでしょうか。

タグをつけられたくないし、出身は自分で決められることではないし、もし出身の質問に答えさせられるなら、「地球だ」が一番ふさわしいと思います。これはちょっと責任逃れ気味ですが、本気で解決方法を探したら、もちろん法律や制度を変えるのは難しいですが、私たちにできることがないわけではありません。自分とは違う国や背景の人々を平等な目で見たり、理解したり、受け入れたりするのはそう難しくないと思います。皆さん、一人一人が地球市民として、この世界が一つになれるように、一緒に頑張ってみませんか？

fields.body:
“Every morning I wake up, I am the person I was yesterday.” This is such an intuitive thought that no one would ever bother to confirm before they hop out of bed and embrace the new day. “If I am not who I was yesterday, then who could I become?” However, when I attempted to corroborate this intuition with logic, I was bungled by its unbelievable fragileness and failed to convince myself. With further contemplation, I gave up solving this single question about person identity (or continuity of a person, or the “same-person-as-before” property); instead, I deemed it more logically appropriate to ask three distinct but related sub-questions addressing extrospective, introspective and omniscient personal identity: “how can we know that another person is the same person as before?”(Extrospective); “how can I know that I am the same person as before?”(Introspective); “how can the omniscient God know that a person is the same person as before?”(Omniscient). These three questions are ordered from the most commonsensical to the most philosophical and each of them requires its own unique corroborative evidences because different perspective is granted a different extent of information that is accessible. Following the discussion of these three sub-questions, I found that a general inquiry about the criteria for person continuity without any perspective is indefinite. However, if I have to propose an answer (as most people might not be so interested in reading through this long-winded paper), the most reasonable criteria would be memory because it is the only factor that is crucial to and indispensible for all three sub-perspectives.
Extrospective “How can we know that another person is the same person as before?” Extrospective personal identity is the most straightforward part because we are actually answering the question about it almost every minute in any social setting and actively using the answer as guidelines for our intrapersonal behaviors. In most situations, we convince ourselves that say John is the same person as he was yesterday (or congruously, anytime in the past) by comparing the reality – the facial appearance and body characteristics of John in front of us – with our memory about John. This reality/memory (more precisely, the observer’s memory) consistency enables us to maintain some magical relationship called friendship because we can extrospectively identify our friends. In some more extreme situations, like John survived a car accident and his/her body was severely deformed, or John went through a bold plastic surgery, we might not able to recognize John by his body or his face, but the reality/memory consistency still holds regarding his name, possessions, or characteristics. Further assume that John changed his name and lost all his possessions after the accident, we should still be able to assure ourselves that this seemingly different person was actually John by recalling and matching the mutual memory we shared. This memory/memory (more precisely, memory of the observee and of the observer) consistency also plays a significant role in those tearful movie scenes where family members separated by war reunion decades later and reconfirm everybody’s identity through narratives of yore. Now, let us extend the reality/memory consistency to the question of self-identity. If we claim that I survive as myself if only my memory is consistent with the current reality, then it seems that I can survive as almost anybody on the earth at a given moment since I am not the only person that possesses a memory that is compliant with the current reality. Unfortunately, we need to come up with another theorem for introspective identity.
Introspective “How can I know that I am the same person as before?” First let us consider a continuously conscious period (a period of time one is able to be aware of and process outward inputs, retrieve and generate memory) and two infinitely close moments t1 and t2 during the period. [IMG *= twomoments.jpg 200px] If I at t1 (say I1) have an internal thought T, I at t2 (say I2) must have the correct memory that “I2 remember that I1 had thought T” provided these two moments are close enough to prevent any memory distortion from happening. Therefore, the exactly accurate thought T is accessible to I2 since it has been cited in I2’s memory. The definition of thought assumes the exclusivity of thought to only one person the thinker, but the abovementioned proof induces that both I1 and I2 have the permission of access. Hence I1 is the same as I2. Applying this proof along the time line, we can confidently claim that I am always the same person as long as I remain conscious. I named this theorem “echo theorem” because the memory is pretty like an echo that convinces us the actions we just did. Unfortunately, it is impossible to stay conscious for even more than one day because we have the most common unconscious experience sleep every night. Thus, can “echo theorem” still work for periods like sleep? Neurobiology tells us that the brain is not completely inactive during the sleep. Many parts of the cortex are considerably active during REM sleep while they are relatively quiescent but not blackout during NREM sleep. [REF *= Craig Heller. “Neurobiology of sleep and dreaming”: lecture for Thinking Matters 41 (Spring ‘14) “The philosophy and biology of consciousness, memory, and personal identity” at Stanford University. May 1, 2014.] So we cannot deny the possibility of a subconscious version of “echo theorem” applied to the sleeping state when there are still continuous activities going on in the brain. For example, if the introspective question happens to occur to us during the dream, we seem to take for granted that the protagonist of the dreamed world is “I”. In other words, this presumption must be yielded by our inner subconscious logic. (If you can’t buy this, you might skip to the second half of this session) The theorem even applies to people in other unconscious states like coma or vegetative state, since scientists observed activities in the posteromedial cortex of patients in recoverable coma and vegetative state. [REF *= Laureys, Steven, Adrian M. Owen, and Nicholas D. Schiff. “Brain function in coma, vegetative state, and related disorders.” The Lancet Neurology 3.9 (2004): 537-546.] There might be an objection to “echo theorem” stating that the theorem becomes undoubtedly ineffectual when identifying a person who undergoes a period of extremely low brain activity or brain death. As far as we know, brain death is irrecoverable. So the person will never have the opportunity to find his/her introspective personal identity and the question actually becomes invalid. But we might still be able to recognize that person because certain criteria of extrospective identity can be satisfied. However, if this unlucky person was also disfigured, the same time all other clues required for reality/memory consistency were missing, the extrospective question might turn out to be indecisive. This begs for a third angle of personal identity independent of anybody’s perspective that we’ll discuss later in the paper. “Echo theorem” is one great approach to introspective identity. Nevertheless, our instinct is not willing to accept this complicated explanation of the supposition that I am who I was. In fact, if we dig deeper into this question “am I who I was”, it came to light that introspection always returns yes. In other words, we always believe that we’re who we were before introspectively. This sounds unbelievable at the first moment, so let us consider an example about the conscious moment of now. [IMG *= momentnow.jpg 300px] My current state is represented by the orange dot in the above diagram. My introspective past is all the memory I possess. If I were asking the question to myself at this moment, “am I the person I was in the past”, I would say yes because introspectively I remembered that it was I who broke one leg in middle school and it was I who dated a girl with red hair. Since past is totally created by my subjective memory and there is no referable past reality in introspection, I define the person I am as the person I was, the person I was as the person I am. Say I, as a man, wake up one morning and find myself turned into a woman. I know I am a woman now and I remembered I was a man yesterday, but the first I is still the same as the second I, with only the property of gender changed. Considering Daniel C. Dennett’s story “Where Am I”, after re-embodiment, the protagonist knows that “I” am Fortinbras now and “I” was Dennett several years ago [REF *= Dennett, D. C. Brainstorms: Philosophical Essays On Mind and Psychology. 1st MIT Press ed. Cambridge, Mass.: MIT Press, 1981.], but the first I is also the same as the second I, with only the accessory body changed. So the introspective identity is actually a little boring since everything in the introspective past just survives to the current in self-perspective. To reinforce this argument, let us consider one more thought experiment. [IMG *= Beckham.jpg 600px] I am Michael but mysteriously I woke up one morning claiming myself to be Beckham even though I had the same appearance and body shape as Michael. If I could remember that I was Michael yesterday then I would make up some reasons quickly to convince myself that something supernatural happened and my past self as Michael sneakily turned into my current self as Beckham but these two selves are both myself. If I could not remember that I was Michael yesterday and believed I am Beckham from the very beginning, there is even less trouble accepting that I am the person I was before. So, the limited access to the real past nullifies the possibility of a mutative introspective identity and pushes it into an infinite self-defining loop. On the other hand, Michael/Beckham’s extrospective identity will change over time from Michael gradually to Beckham. At the first moment people would regard the new Michael as the old Michael because of body similarity. But when the time goes on, since the new Michael always claims to be Beckham and exhibits extraordinary talent in soccer and flawless native English, people will eventually admit that Michael has changed to Beckham, and the person now is not the same one as the original Michael. Even so, we have yet been able to answer the question does Michael survive after the accident in the scenario of the previous example. Both extrospective and introspective identities are both based on some point of view while survival is more independent and objective. Also recalling the objection earlier in the paper that appeals for a solution when both extrospective and introspective identities fail, we would like to continue to the last sub-question on omniscient personal identity.
Omniscient “How can the omniscient God know that a person is the same person as before?” In the extrospective view, the observer can access the memory of itself, the narrative memory of the observee and the ongoing reality. In the introspective view, the observer, also its own observee, can access the memory of itself and the ongoing reality. In contrast to these two relatively realistic settings, the omniscient setting entitles the observer to access both people’s memories and past and ongoing realities. Continuing the previous example about Michael and Beckham, it is intuitive to think that Michael survives if the new Michael (or Beckham) is able to recall the memory of being Michael and this memory matches the past reality. So for omniscient identity, a person survives as another subsequent person if his/her conscious experience matches the memory of the subsequent person. [IMG *= survive.jpg 300px] In the above diagram, the memory of I2 matches the actual past conscious experience of I. Thus, I survives as I2 omnisciently. This also fits into the most mundane schemes so that we can convince ourselves that a normal person survives overnight since his/her memory at the second morning matches his/her conscious experience the previous day. It’s a little tricky here to say the actual past conscious experience because I am referring to the reality regarding a person’s past mental state not the objective exterior reality. Just imagine an adventurer traversing a dessert. He witnessed a mirage and remembered seeing that illusory oasis in retrospect. The comparison is drawn between what he remembered (mirage of oasis) and what he actually experienced in the past (oasis) not what the objective world was (deadly dessert). Now, let us consider some more fictional scenarios and apply the omniscient identity hypothesis. [IMG *= copy.jpg 300px] If both I1 and I2 have the memory congruent to the conscious experience of I, I survives as both I1 and I2 and they are the same at the moment showed in the diagram. But they start to differ when the time elapses because the new conscious experience they gain differs from each other. Extrospectively, we have to admit that both I1 and I2 were our old friend I. This sounds weird now because the entire scenario is not realistic up to current technology and people just cannot accept it. [IMG *= exchange.jpg 450px] If I1 and I2 change minds (or brains, if physicalism is true), I1, previously in Body 1, continues to survive in Body 2 while I2, previously in Body 2, continues to survive in Body 1. This implies that a person’s omniscient identity is largely determined by the identity of the mind, which is consistent with the popular viewpoints among philosophers. [REF *= Perry, John. A Dialogue On Personal Identity and Immortality Indianapolis: Hackett Pub. Co. 1978.][REF *= Thomas Nagel. “Brain Bisection and the Unity of Consciousness.” Synthese, Vol. 22, No. 3/4 (May, 1971), pp. 396-413.] [IMG *= amnesia.jpg 300px] Then what about complete amnesia? Since I’ does not have any memory, I ceases to exist and I’ is a brand new person at this moment. However, I’ can also be the same person as I extrospectively and external forces like parents and friends telling I’ everything happened to him/her in the past might able to rebuild the memory of I’ and eventually retrieve the survival of I. There exists a problem here: can I’ actually rebuild the original memory in the format “I remember I did …” or can he/she only be able to rebuild a quasi-original memory in the format “I remember somebody told me that I did …”. This needs further discussion. [IMG *= sequence.jpg 350px] Finally, I would like to refute an objection claiming that the unreliability of memory can result in the demise of a person under the omniscient view. If I forget some past experience, then that past self no longer survives. This argument is spurious because if our memory of day T-1 at day T matches the conscious experience of day T-1, our memory of day T-2 at day T-1 matches the conscious experience of day T-2, … our memory of day 0 at day 1 matches the conscious experience of day 0, it induces a chain of equalities that strings all the selves up into a single identity. Our memory of day 0 at day T could be deteriorated, but we do not require that to match the conscious experience of day 0. We only expect the validity of the memory for one day. If this is still too long for memory to remain intact, we can induce an even stronger conclusion by replacing days with minutes, seconds, all the way until infinitesimal time laps. Similar to the proof of “echo theorem”, this guarantees the reliability of memory and evades the assumption of the objection.
In conclusion, it is necessary to split the question about personal identity into three dimensions: extrospective, introspective and omniscient because they need completely different approaches and behave differently even incompatibly for peculiar scenarios. As I mentioned in the opening, memory is the only candidate that bridges all these three perspectives. The paper justified most of this hypothesis while raised some controversies and plausible corollaries for further discussion. After all, personal identity deserves one of the hardest problems in philosophy.

国の経済を助けながら文化を変える人があまりいないが、秋元康は二つのことをした。秋元は日本の作詞家でAKB48のグループを作った人だ。すごく人気がある音楽を書いたから、日本の音楽を聞いた人が増えた。挑発的な歌詞を書いて日本人に文化の問題を考えさせた。それに、AKB48は普通の女の子に歌手になねるパワーをあげた。それにしても、アメリカで秋元が知っている人が少ない。だから、秋元康は「Unsung Hero」だ。

秋元は1958年に東京都目黒区大橋で、サラリーマンの家庭に生まれた。小学生のころは、病気になっても、成績がよく、クラスで一番いい生徒の一つだった。だから、東京大学に入る夢を持っていた。しかし、なぜか分からないが秋元はよい中学校の入学試験に落ちて、普通の中学校に入った。その失敗のため、中学生から高校生のころ、東大に入る夢を忘れて、遊んでばかりいてあまり勉強しなかった。高校二年生になった1975年の冬、ニッポン放送「せんだみつおの足かけ二日大進撃」という番組を聞いて、そんな番組を僕も書けると思って、勉強のノートに「せんだみつお」についてのパロディを書いた。同級生たちにこのパロディを見せて、みんなほめてくれたから、そのパロディをニッポン放送に送ってみた。放送作家の奥山コーシンがそれを気に入ったから、秋元は奥山の学生となり、放送作家として番組のスクリプトなどを書き始めた。

放送作家になった後で秋元はうれしかったとは限らない。19歳だけだったのに、もらった給料が高くて、普通のサラリーマンの給料の4倍をもらうほどだったが、この仕事はやさしすぎると思った。人気があるプログラムを書いたが、新しい仕事がほしかったので、80年代から歌を書く人になった。この仕事に入る前に、少し成功したけれども、日本人が秋元の名前を聞いたことがあまりなかった。だから、JPOPの「The Alfee」というグループで働いた。「The Alfee」にたくさん歌を書いてあげた。例えば、「オールナイトフジ」とか、「タやけニャンニャン」はすごく成功したから、有名な作詞家は秋元と聞いたことがあった。人々は秋元の書いた歌が好きだ、それは秋元にとってとても重要なことだった。それから、もっと影響力を求めたくて、何か新しいことをしてみたいと考え、1985年に「おニャン子クラブ」という大きい女性アイドルグループを作った。その時から、「おニャンこクラブ」が生まれて、グループの作詞家とプロデュースとして勤めている秋元は有名になり始めた。

この「おニャン子クラブ」のメンバーはすべて若い女子高生で、高校で勉強しながら活動していた。アイドルらしいディスタンスがない同級生のようなメンバーはすぐに人気を集め、翌1986年このグループは大成功になった。しかし、その成功はせっかく出たのに、1年間しか続いていなかった。アイドルは健康的なイメージを伝えるべきだけど、たばこを吸ったり、学校で悪い成績ばかり取ったり、恋愛をしたりするメンバーがいるというゴシップが出で来たし、メンバーに興味があるファンが少なくならないためメンバーのアップデートを速くしたから、人気が少なくなってしまった。それで、「おニャン子クラブ」は1987年解散した。成功と言っても、失敗と言っても、「おニャン子クラブ」は秋元にとって大事な未来ヘの布石となった。それから、秋元は1989年に発表された、昭和時代にとても有名な美空ひばりが歌った「川の流れのように」を作詞した。この曲は美空が病死する前の最後の歌だったし、1997年にNHKで20世紀の日本で一番偉い曲として選ばれたから、この曲の作詞家の秋元康は日本でみんなが知っている有名人になった。

100パーセントの成功と言わない「おニャン子クラブ」から、秋元が習った経験は多かった。2005年その経験を持っている秋元は20年ぶりの新しいアイドルグループを作った。グループはテレビでパフォームしないで毎日秋葉原でパフォームしたから、「AKB48」と呼んだ。秋葉原にあるAKB48の「NOKIA THEATRE」ヘ「会いに行ける」というスローガンはとても大事だった。パフォーマンスの後でファンはAKB48のメンバーと握手できた。しかし、AKB48が生まれた時、すぐに人気が出なかった。その時、人はあまりAKB48と聞かなかった。最初のパフォーマンスの時、切符を売れなくて、七人しか来なかった。とても大変だけど、メンバーは秋元から応援してもらって、毎日泣いても一生懸命に練習していた。それから、秋葉原だけじゃなくて、日本中有名になりたいので、ちょっと挑発的な歌詞を歌ったが、残念ながら何も起こらなかった。例えば、「制服が邪魔をする」という歌のテーマは女性の初めてのセックスについてだった。そして、2008年音楽レーベルさえなくしてしまった。その間にAKB48をやめたメンバーもいたし、AKB48の未来を見られないメンバーもいたけれども、秋元康はAKB48をやめたくなくて、ずっとAKB48が人気がある日を待っていた。

2005年から四年間続けて秋葉原の小さいシアターでパフォーマンスを行っていたAKB48は、実に甲子園に出場できるように毎日学校の野球場で練習している高校野球チームと似ている。甲子園は高校野球チームの夢だが、東京ドームはAKB48にとって夢の場所だった。2009年、14番目のシングル「RIVER」が初めてオリコン１位になった後で、少女たちはついに夜明けを見た。それから、2010年18番目のシングル「Beginner」が初めて百万枚以上売れたことや、2011年「第53回日本レコード大賞」をもらったことや、2012年ついに東京ドームで「1830m」というコンサートを行ったことなど、秋元のAKB48は日本音楽のピークに立つようになった。秋元は「おニャン子クラブ」からたくさん経験を学んだから、AKB48が同じ間違いを二度しないように、イノベーションをいっぱいすることにした。例えば、恋愛のゴシップで男性ファンがなくならないように、メンバーが絶対に恋愛をしてはいけないという厳しいルールを作った。それに、大きいグループの中に小さいクリクがあったら、グループの皆は友達になりにくて、喧嘩がよく起こるので、クリクが見つけられたら、このクリクのメンバーが全部AKB48を離れさせられるルールもあった。それから、グループの人数が多いので、ファンにとってシングルを歌えるメンバーを選ぶのがもっとフェアになるために、2009年から「選抜総選挙」というファンがメンバーを投票するシステムによってシングルメンバーを決めた。そして、東京から全国に、それからアジアにまでも広げたいから、秋元はAKB48以外に名古屋のSKE48を始め、大阪のNMB 48、福岡のHKT48、インドネシア・ジャカルタのJKT48、中国・上海のSNH48などのシスターグループを作った。

2010年秋元はびっくりした。大きい賞をもらったが、この賞はちょっと変な賞だった。名前は「Good Design Award」で、普通に産物にあげて、人には全然あげない賞だ。AKB48がこの賞をもらった理由は、普通の女子が踊りと歌がすごく上手になれることだとは限らない、一生懸命に頑張っている女性のイメージと物語を「売る」ことによって、日本の経済を助けて、社会を動かしたことだった。2002年の前に日本の音楽インダストリーはちょっと困っていた。たくさん人気があるグループがなかったから、AKB48は音楽インダストリーを活性化した。それに、AKB48の音楽は日本人の気持ちを変えられた。「恋するフォーチュンクッキー」という曲は素晴らしい例だ。この歌はとてもうれしくて、気持ちがいいから、歌を聞いた人は短い時間に政治と経済の問題を忘れて、日本社会の未来を信じるようになる。AKB48のビデオ以外に、たくさん普通の日本人も「恋するフォーチュンクッキー」のビデオを作ってYOUTUBEにアプロードした。ファン以外にいろいろな政治家もビデオを作った。アイドルの音楽を聞きながら人々は夢を見られる、これはやはりアイドルの仕事だ。だから、日本中いろいろな人はこの歌を歌ったり、踊ったりするのが大好きだった。

秋元のAKB48の未来はどうなるかわからないけれども、みんなで楽しめるすばらしい曲を書いたし、「おニャン子クラブ」と「AKB48」のアイドルグループを作ったし、秋元の人生はもう素晴らしかったと言える。失敗してももう一度やってみることや、自分が好きなことを一生懸命にすることや、音楽とアイドルが社会に役立てることなど、秋元の人生が教えてくれることは、音楽やアイドルより彼からの一番大きいギフトだ。だから、秋元康は私たちが選んだ「Unsung Hero」なのだ。
